body:
Hmm, this is due to that you run setup.py but seems without the shared library compiled, so you can find the python picks the python library in site-package, without the shared library. 

Try to delete /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/tvm-0.1.0-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg and use the python path again to prioritize the pythonpath on your code path
in general we prefer the developer mode to NOT install it explicitly, but simply set python path, so that the shared library can get updated in source.
@sxjscience Do you know if we need a higher version of MSVC?

that could be
it seems that lamda expression is not well support in MSVC14.
as far as i know @sxjscience successfully compiled tvm under windows. We should add a minimum version requirement to the installation doc
I'm using VS 2015 Update 3
ok , i will try later, thanks
That is, use method1 here http://docs.tvmlang.org/how_to/install.html#python-package-installation
@sxjscience can you open a PR to installation guide to add the minimum requirement? Thanks!
@tqchen OK, I'll do it soon.
That fixed it. Seeing soft hang, will debug it.
you can close this issue, it works now by using VS 2015 Update 3. thanks.

global barrier is usually a feature that is not supported by GPUs(Nvidia add that support recently). it means the ability to sync all threads launched. This is used in persistent threading model where all thread launches and communicate through the shared global memory.

This mechanism is needed in things like NCCL or persistent RNNs.  The current implementation of global barrier is hacky, where we have a global variable counter and keeps each thread block spin until the counter gets to a desired value. It is not guanranteed to work, unless all the required thread block launches. The next generation CUDA add official support for this

This is a feature that is not needed except for persistent RNNs, and I am not sure the current hack will work for AMD GPUs. So I would recommend start without it, and add a solution back later if necessary.
also need to add import to here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/__init__.py#L19

The support for compiling into TVM will happen at upstream frameworks (e.g. mxnet and other frameworks uses dlpack). TVM will remain as a standalone module that the upstream frameworks can use, and we can expect changes in the upstream frameworks soon
Seems to be problem of importing numpy in the python env. Can you check simply import numpy on the board ?

I tested on my laptop. It seems the benchmark result is not stable.

Indeed! I found there's a problem with `numpy` and failed to re-install numpy with same error. I'm trying to update `numpy` using `pip install -U numpy`.

import failed: lapack_lite.so: undefined symbol: zungqr_ · Issue #9597 · numpy/numpy
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/9597#issuecomment-324841263
closing this issue now as it is problem of numpy

For compilation in i7, we might need to switch AVX optimization on, by set target to
```llvm -mcpu=core-avx2```

though the example may not be optimized for this setting

Yes, this is a problem caused by the limitation of my experiment environment. All the experiments are done on an old MacBook. I do not think Mac OSX has that flexible thread pool configuration, just as it is mentioned in [Halide README](https://github.com/halide/Halide).

`````````
weng@octa:~/tvm/tutorials/python$ python opt_gemm.py #The default setting

`````````

Thus, further study is required for multi-thread optimization.
could because you used the wrong target triple
try to do gcc -v on the board to see the target triple you have

Successful cross-compilation and some notes below:

According to tutorial [Cross Compilation and RPC
](http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html), I edit this line `f = tvm.build(s, [A, B], target='llvm -target=aarch64-linux-gnu', name='myadd')` in `cross_compilation_and_rpc.py` on local machine using matched target value. Check matched target value using `gcc -v` on remote device (board).

## successful message on board
```shell
yuanshuai@firefly:~$ python -m tvm.exec.rpc_server --host 0.0.0.0 --port=9090
Loading runtime library /home/yuanshuai/code/tvm/lib/libtvm_runtime.so... exec only
INFO:root:RPCServer: bind to 0.0.0.0:9090
INFO:root:RPCServer: connection from ('192.168.1.110', 33898)
INFO:root:Connection from ('192.168.1.110', 33898)
[02:12:11] src/runtime/rpc/rpc_server_env.cc:23: Upload /tmp/tmpWg05yI/mylib.o... nbytes=5096
INFO:root:Create shared library based on /tmp/tmpWg05yI/mylib.o
INFO:root:load_module /tmp/tmpWg05yI/mylib.o.so
[02:12:11] src/runtime/rpc/rpc_session.cc:751: Shutdown...
INFO:root:Finish serving ('192.168.1.110', 33898)
```

## successful message on local machine

```shell
yuens@Spark:~/Software/tvm/tutorials/python$ python cross_compilation_and_rpc.py 
[10:12:11] src/codegen/llvm/codegen_llvm.cc:75: set native vector to be 32 for target aarch64
2.65708e-05 secs/op
```

Also note that if you want to do CPU testing, it might make sense to add detailed target options, for example

```-mattr=+neon```

to enable neon support
@tqchen Get!
@were  I think your numpy result is still too slow. I believe 0.03~0.06 is a reasonable number.

Can you give more detailed information, such as platform info., X86 or embedded device? or any failed logs?

There's an [installation guide](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/docs/how_to/install.md), which can guide you install TVM on local machine. Besides, [another link](http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#declare-and-cross-compile-kernel-on-local-machine) can guide you use cross-compilation.
```
With cross compilation and RPC, you can compile program on your local machine then run
it on remote device. It is useful when the resource of remote device is limited, like
Raspberry Pi and mobile platforms, so you do not wish to put the compilation procedure
on the device in order to save time and space.
```

 "tvm/lib" 
into folder: 
"/home/jjs/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/tvm-0.1.0-py3.5-linux-x86_64.egg/tvm/"

@fivejjs I'm not sure whether this problem is about environment varibles, but you can have a try to export relative environment variable to `~/.bashrc` as below (set yourself `TVM_HOME` value):
```shell
# add tvm
export TVM_HOME=~/Software/tvm
export PYTHONPATH=$TVM_HOME/python:${PYTHONPATH}
```
After that, enable updated `~/.bashrc` using `source ~/.bashrc`.   

_Sent from my Meizu m1 metal using [FastHub](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.fastaccess.github)_
Sorry, this is because `CUDA_HOME` was used for the directory in the system, not `CUDA_PATH`
For .exist, we should use HSA API instead of HIP RT API.

Hi @tqchen ,
The test is still failing.
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test_runtime_ndarray.py", line 16, in <module>
    ENABLED_CTX_LIST = enabled_ctx_list()
  File "test_runtime_ndarray.py", line 12, in enabled_ctx_list
    assert tvm.context(k, 0) == v
  File "/home/aditya/tvm/python/tvm/_ffi/ndarray.py", line 59, in context
    raise ValueError("Unknown device type %s" % dev_type)
ValueError: Unknown device type rocm
```

This is because of this https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/_ffi/ndarray.py#L58, and we need to update python file here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/_ffi/runtime_ctypes.py#L94 to include rocm

STR2MASK field
Can you review the build error too?
The java test error was due to the fact that libhip_hcc was not in LD_LIBRARY_PATH, will submit another PR to fix this

The new commit is making the test pass:
```
$ python test_runtime_ndarray.py
[10:44:58] src/codegen/verilog/vpi_device_api.cc:31: Initialize VPI simulated ram 32MB ...
('Testing using contexts:', [cpu(0), rocm(0), vpi(0)])
```'

Also, please review https://github.com/dmlc/dlpack/pull/15
Thanks for reporting this! It should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/380

BTW, the commits seems to be a bit messed up because you used the pull merge to pull upstream changes. Usually we use rebase upstream/master http://docs.tvmlang.org/how_to/contribute.html#how-to-resolve-conflict-with-master

@tqchen Ready to merge.
I'll provide documents in another PR (and java runtime documents)

Gotcha. I was going to create a new PR anyway.

Can you update the submodule commit for dlpack?
You can do that in the new PR I am going to close this one for  now then
Do a git pull in the submodule folder and commit on the root, will bring dlpack to the new version
Can you merge the pull request https://github.com/dmlc/dlpack/pull/15 ?
merged, was waiting for the CI to pass
@tqchen review?

There's a problem about using `tvm.ndarray`. After modified as below, it's fixed.
```python
a = tvm.nd.array(a.asnumpy().astype(dtype), ctx)
b = tvm.nd.array(b.asnumpy().astype(dtype), ctx)
c = tvm.nd.array(c.asnumpy().astype(dtype), ctx)
```
the default rtol of numpy is quite high, consider use a bigger rtol to, use assert_allcose with rtol
@tqchen I faced the similiar problem. For the default schedule, the test passed, but after applying several optimizations, I have to release the eps to pass `numpy.testing.assert_allclose`.
It is possible, because the summation order becomes different so the exact number may not match exactly
Yeah, I know. It is caused by the mechanism of float point add.
Good effort!
That error is not the same error as the numpy one - lapack_lite and liblapack are different things, and only the former is owned by numpy

If you have a RasPi, just clone this repo. Then go to `make/config.mk` to set `USE_RPC=1`, type `make runtime`.

Then follow [this](http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-cross-compilation-and-rpc-py) to use RPC.

The schedule on rasp pi will be released in this week


On Fri, Aug 25, 2017 at 08:15 Jian Weng <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> If you have a RasPi, just clone this repo. Then go to make/config.mk to
> set USE_RPC=1, type make runtime.
>
> Then follow this
> <http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-cross-compilation-and-rpc-py>
> to use RPC.
>

Ziheng Jiang
Fudan University | Computer Science
Need to add /usr/local/cuda/ to CUDA_PATH, seems ADD_CFLAGS does not take effect in here
I think it is a non-ssue, should use numpy.testing.assert_allclose with released rtol
@tqchen , can you help me understand what part is failing?
need to add things to here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/c_runtime_api.cc#L29
Did add it though. https://github.com/adityaatluri/tvm/blob/rocm-init-v2/src/runtime/c_runtime_api.cc#L33
OK was due to the jenkins sometimes cache an old version of the build to do incremental build to save time and did not update the build. Let mean clean the workspace and retrigger the build
I couldn't understand the source of the error. Is it normal that loading add_cpu.so loads all dependency rt libraries?
Yes, when we do import tvm, i think it will load in the dependent runtime library, and somehow HSA cannot be loaded when there is no devices available?

OK for now I think it might be better to not include rocm related stuffs into the linked libraries. We will just verifies that it compiles in the jenkins ci for now. Changed in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/387

Here is the log:
https://gist.github.com/adityaatluri/6f2cff50fd762aa83a4fd8772c124df0

OK, please rebase against master. During running tests, enable LLVM and USE_RPC=1, this should be able to let you pass unittest. For now, we only need tests/python/unittests/test_runtime_ndarray to pass and rocm buffer works.

Later we might need to check the compiled libraries results
Do you plan to run tests once AMD GPU gets added to CI?
need to tweak the test env a bit. We currently relies on docker for building test env and need to check if anything like nv-docker is available
For now let us do local verifications of tests
Can you cook up test script for it so that I can report it for every pull request I create?
The two script I listed before  should be fine, as long as you build with rpc and llvm enabled
need to rebase against latest master
Thanks very much.

This problem still exits after adding `CUDA_PATH` and relative env. variables into `~/.bashrc`.
## ~/.bashrc
```shell
# cuda
export CUDA_HOME=/usr/local/cuda
export PATH=$CUDA_HOME/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$CUDA_HOME/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
```
After addition, I updated using `source ~/.bashrc` and `make runtime` again as below:

./cuda_runtime.h

Seems you didn't check in schedule elemwise

I found a mistake in my `config.mk` in this line:
```mk
ADD_CFLAGS = -l/usr/local/cuda/include
```
It's okay after changing `-l`(letter L) to `-I`(letter i) and setting `USE_CUDNN` value `0` in `config.mk`:
```shell
yuanshuai@tegra-ubuntu:~/sdcard/code/tvm$ make runtime
make: Nothing to be done for 'runtime'.
yuanshuai@tegra-ubuntu:~/sdcard/code/tvm$ ldd lib/libtvm_runtime.so 
        linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x0000007f975ca000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x0000007f974dd000)
        libcuda.so.1 => /usr/lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/tegra/libcuda.so.1 (0x0000007f9664b000)

@adityaatluri The codegen_nvptx.cc and other changes in this PR should be good reference for adding rocm backend

Tvm uses the same llvm backend as clang uses, and actually turns on aggressive memory optimization . maybe there is difference in terms of set of optimization.

I do not know what exactly happens in your case, could due to better cache locality because everything is allocated in global memory consecutively or maybe clang turns on other set of optimizations to optimize the plain code better.

Try follow the tutorial and optimize further, that should brings tvm speed to become faster.

Also if your machine support avx2, set target to be llvm -mcpu=avx2 will help
The option would be -mcpu=core-avx2

What you are asking for seems can be  can be done by rfactor, http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/reduction.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-reduction-py . 

This only allows sum across the threads within the block though, but can be a good starting point

I tried the "-mcpu=core-avx2",  but it produced the same result.
I use func.save('mmul.o') to export the binary file, then take objdump to disassemble it. I find out the tvm version has 256 **mulps** instruction while clang version has only 8 **mulps**. It looks like tvm unrolled the innermost loop and increased the binary code size. This may cause increasing instructions cache missing rate. This may be the reason why tvm is slower. 
Another question: In tvm, I must set the vectorize manually while clang can auto detect it and generate the vectorized code using instructions like **mulps** . Can tvm support auto vectorization like clang?

We can enable auto vectorization pass in LLVM. Though again this won't give us the most effective code. In a nutshell, clang's auto vectorization might work to get us to the medium perf, but using TVM primitives gives possibility to get to the peak

Try to follow the [tutorial](http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/opt_gemm.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-opt-gemm-py) and optimize the gemm a bit further which might help to see the difference.

I have tried that tutorial . I just wanted to know what level the naive code can achieve with clang and find this problem in the progress.

Thanks very much for your patience.

Putting aside the atomic (global) add, the major problem then becomes this line: 
xo, xi = s[Weight_grad].split(s[Weight_grad].op.axis[0], factor=32) 

I thought s[Weight_grad].op.axis[0] could be the fh, fw, or c axis, but it turns out to be a small value and so it is not efficient to bind to the threads and blocks. I could not bind the fh, fw, or c axis to the threadIdx.x and blockIdx.x anymore. Is there anyway I could bind them?

xo, xi = s[Weight_grad].split(c, factor=32), error message is 
Operate on iter var iter_var(c, Range(min=0, extent=64))that is not part of the schedule

Thank you!

I think I was confused of the s[Weight_grad].op.axis and Weight_grad.op.axis. They are in fact the same but it seems to me we can only write s[Weight_grad].split(s[Weight_grad].op.axis[0], factor=32) instead of s[Weight_grad].split(Weight_grad.op.axis, factor=32).

I think the OpenCL runtime is different from what AMD is doing for HIP and MIOpen, which is their new focus for machine learning based on the ROCm platform. So to have better support for AMD GPUs, adding a separate backend seems reasonable.
When we do rfactor, s[weight_grad].op get rewritten to another operator which is different from weight_grad.op. So it is always safe to call s[Weight_grad].split(s[Weight_grad].op.axis[0], factor=32)
